TEXT: CARDINAL . PERSON , a commercial traveller of NORP nationality , resided at PERSON ( GPE ) at the material time .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant arrived at GPE airport from GPE . The customs officers found QUANTITY of heroin in the suitcase of another passenger on the same flight , PERSON When asked whether he had been travelling with someone else , the latter pointed out the applicant . PERSON explained that they were both part of a group ; he was searched and , when nothing was found , released .

CARDINAL . After further investigations , he was none the less suspected of being linked to PERSON , as a result of which he was arrested on DATE at GPE , on the train on which he was returning to GPE .
CARDINAL . Mr Imbrioscia immediately sought the help of PERSON , who contacted a lawyer , PERSON

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was questioned by the GPE district prosecutor ( GPE ) with the assistance of an interpreter . He stated that he had caught the plane at GPE because it was the cheapest way of travelling to GPE . By pure coincidence another person had also bought a ticket at PERSON for the same flight , but they had never sat next to each other during the trip . In addition , he denied that he had been involved in importing drugs into GPE . When he was advised that he was being remanded in custody , he requested that a lawyer be assigned to him as he did not know any lawyers in GPE .
He remained in custody in the building of the GPE district prosecutor ’s department .
CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON wrote to Mr Imbrioscia offering to represent him . He returned the necessary authority to act to her after signing it .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL and CARDINAL DATE the police interrogated him without his lawyer being present .
On DATE he was questioned by a GPE district prosecutor and he asked to be confronted with PERSON , in order to prove his innocence .

CARDINAL . On DATE PERSON withdrew as the applicant ’s lawyer . The available documents do not show to what extent she had participated in his defence , but it is apparent from the prison register that she never visited him .

On DATE Mr PERSON was officially assigned to act for Mr Imbrioscia and on DATE was given permission to visit him , which he did for the first time on DATE . On CARDINAL DATE the case file that had been sent to him for inspection on DATE was returned by him to the district prosecutor ’s office .

CARDINAL . Mr Imbrioscia was questioned again by the district prosecutor on DATE . PERSON had not been invited to attend the interview and does not seem to have asked to be present , but he received a transcript of it . On DATE he visited the applicant .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL and DATE the district prosecutor and QUANTITY police officers went to PERSON to examine several witnesses , including CARDINAL travel agents .

CARDINAL . On DATE Mr Imbrioscia ’s lawyer had a conversation with the district prosecutor , the subject of which is a matter of dispute . According to the judgment delivered by ORG ) on DATE ( see paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL below ) , the district prosecutor told the lawyer that his client would be questioned again on DATE . Mr PERSON denies this and claims that the discussion centred on the applicant ’s detention .
In any event , he was not present on DATE when PERSON was questioned about the inconsistencies in his statements and disputed the findings of the inquiries made in GPE .

CARDINAL . By a letter of CARDINAL DATE Mr PERSON acknowledged receipt of the transcripts of the ORG statements in PERSON and of the questioning on DATE ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and DATE above ) , and complained that he had not been invited to attend . He visited Mr Imbrioscia DATE .

CARDINAL . Mr PERSON was , on the other hand , present on DATE when the applicant was informed that the preliminary investigation had been concluded and that he faced possible charges of heroin smuggling and forgery . Mr PERSON stated that he had had nothing to do with the matters of which he was accused under the first head and that he had acted in good faith as regards the second . His lawyer remained silent .
CARDINAL . On DATE the district prosecutor ’s office committed Mr Imbrioscia and PERSON for trial in LOC ( Bezirksgericht ) for drug trafficking .
On DATE Mr PERSON visited his client in prison .
CARDINAL . At the hearing on DATE the CARDINAL accused were again questioned about the facts , and their counsel made their submissions . PERSON also examined M.

The court convicted the applicant and his co - defendant of offences against the dangerous drugs legislation ( Betäubungsmittelgesetz ) . It sentenced Mr Imbrioscia to DATE imprisonment and banned him from residing in GPE for DATE ; his co - defendant was given a DATE prison sentence . The defendants were each ordered to pay CARDINAL the costs of the proceedings .

CARDINAL . The court noted that the applicant had contradicted himself on several occasions - as to whether he knew PERSON first name and surname , whether he had sat next to him in the aeroplane and so on . Having regard to these inconsistencies , it considered that the accused ’s claim that he was innocent could no longer be taken seriously ( nicht mehr ernstgenommen werden kann ) .

PERSON , who was illiterate , had also made such contradictory statements that there were doubts as to his mental capacity ; he could not therefore be regarded as having been the organiser of the drug smuggling . On the last occasion he was questioned , on CARDINAL DATE , he had moreover stated that his co - defendant had been with him continuously and had told him when he should take delivery of the suitcase . Mr PERSON ’s role had therefore been to assist and supervise M.
The court found that the applicant had knowingly and willingly participated in committing the offence .

CARDINAL . On DATE , after a hearing during which Mr Imbrioscia was again questioned by the judges , in Mr PERSON ’s presence , ORG ( Obergericht ) dismissed his appeal ( GPE ) . It upheld the sentence imposed by ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) and in addition ordered the applicant to pay the costs of the appeal proceedings .

CARDINAL . As regards his lawyer ’s absence during the interviews it observed that the lawyer had been informed of DATE but had not attended , and that he had not put any questions at the last interview on DATE , which he had attended ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . Nor had the appellant shown how his defence had been adversely affected .

On the merits , the court followed the trial court ’s reasoning ; it considered it scarcely plausible that CARDINAL people who did not know each other should have travelled together from GPE to GPE and back via GPE and have stayed in GPE in the same hotel .
CARDINAL . An application by PERSON to ORG ( Kassationsgericht ) for a declaration of nullity ( PERSON ) was dismissed on DATE .

With regard to the complaint based on the fact that no lawyer was present at the interviews , ORG referred to the case - law of ORG ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . The applicant had not alleged that he had asked to have his lawyer present and that his request had been rejected on irrelevant grounds ( unsachliche GPE ) ; his lawyer had , moreover , attended the interview on DATE and the hearing on DATE ( see paragraphs DATE and DATE above ) .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed a public - law appeal by the applicant against the judgments of CARDINAL DATE and DATE ( see paragraphs CARDINAL above ) .

ORG referred to its case - law concerning LAW para . CARDINAL of LAW of the GPE of GPE ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) . It stressed that Mr Imbrioscia had not complained that a request to have his lawyer present had been arbitrarily rejected ; the lawyer had attended the last questioning and had been sent the transcripts of the previous ones . There had therefore been no infringement of the defence rights guaranteed to Mr Imbrioscia under LAW and the Convention .
CARDINAL . At the material time LAW was worded as follows :

" During the investigation counsel for the defence must be granted access to the file in so far as the purposes of the investigation are not thereby jeopardised . He can not be refused the right to inspect reports by experts or transcripts of interviews at which he is entitled to be present .
The investigating law officer may give counsel leave to attend personal interviews with the person charged .
Once the investigation is concluded , counsel for the defence shall have unrestricted access to the file . "

According to ORG case - law , the second paragraph of this provision permits the prosecuting authorities to refuse to allow a lawyer to be present on the first occasion when a suspect is questioned without giving reasons , but requires them to give reasons if they intend to exclude the lawyer from subsequent interviews .
The practice in GPE is that the lawyer does not generally attend when his client is interrogated by the police , but he is usually sent the transcripts .
CARDINAL . The first CARDINAL paragraphs of the LAW cited above were amended on DATE and now provide :

" During the investigation access to the file must be granted to the person charged and to his defence counsel on request , if and in so far as the purposes of the investigation are in no way thereby jeopardised . The right to inspect documents already communicated to the person charged as well as experts’ reports and the transcripts of investigation interviews which counsel for the defence has been given leave to attend can not be refused .

The investigating law officer must give counsel for the defence an opportunity to attend examinations of the person charged if the latter so wishes and if the purposes of the investigation are not likely to be jeopardised . Members of the cantonal Bar must be admitted to examinations once the person charged has made his first statement to the investigating law officer or if he has been in custody for DATE . A defence counsel who attends an examination must be able to put questions to the person charged that are likely to throw light on the case . "
